name: BigQuery
overview:
This class allows you interact with BigQuery.

First, install @google-cloud/bigquery with npm:

$ npm install --save @google-cloud/bigquery

If you are running your app on Google Compute Engine, you won't need to worry about supplying connection configuration options to @google-cloud/bigqueryâ€” we figure that out for you.

However, if you're running your app elsewhere, you will need to provide project details to authenticate API requests.

Google Cloud Platform

var bigquery = require('@google-cloud/bigquery')();

Elsewhere

var bigquery = require('@google-cloud/bigquery')({ projectId: 'grape-spaceship-123', keyFilename: '/path/to/keyfile.json' });

The full set of options which can be passed to @google-cloud/bigquery are outlined in our Authentication guide.

methods.name: BigQuery
methods.description:
In the following examples from this page and the other modules (Dataset, Table, etc.), we are going to be using a dataset from data.gov of higher education institutions.

We will create a table with the correct schema, import the public CSV file into that table, and query it for data.

methods.name: date
methods.description: The DATE type represents a logical calendar date, independent of time zone. It does not represent a specific 24-hour time period. Rather, a given DATE value represents a different 24-hour period when interpreted in different time zones, and may represent a shorter or longer day during Daylight Savings Time transitions.

examples.code: var date = bigquery.date('2017-01-01');

examples.caption: Alternatively, provide an object.

params.name: value
params.description: • The date. If a string, this should be in the format the API describes: YYYY-[M]M-[D]D. Otherwise, provide an object.

methods.name: datetime
methods.description: A DATETIME data type represents a point in time. Unlike a TIMESTAMP, this does not refer to an absolute instance in time. Instead, it is the civil time, or the time that a user would see on a watch or calendar.

examples.code: var datetime = bigquery.datetime('2017-01-01 13:00:00');

examples.caption: Alternatively, provide an object.

params.name: value
params.description: • The time. If a string, this should be in the format the API describes: YYYY-[M]M-[D]D[ [H]H:[M]M:[S]S[.DDDDDD]]. Otherwise, provide an object.

params.name: value.fractional
params.description: • Up to six digits for microsecond precision.

methods.name: time
methods.description: A TIME data type represents a time, independent of a specific date.

examples.code: var time = bigquery.time('14:00:00'); // 2:00 PM

examples.caption: Alternatively, provide an object.

params.name: value
params.description: • The time. If a string, this should be in the format the API describes: [H]H:[M]M:[S]S[.DDDDDD]. Otherwise, provide an object.

params.name: value.fractional
params.description: • Up to six digits for microsecond precision.

methods.name: timestamp
methods.description: A timestamp represents an absolute point in time, independent of any time zone or convention such as Daylight Savings Time.

examples.code: var timestamp = bigquery.timestamp(new Date());
bigquery.createDataset('my-dataset', function(err, dataset, apiResponse) {});

examples.caption: If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

methods.name: createQueryStream
methods.description: Run a query scoped to your project as a readable object stream.

examples.caption: If you anticipate many results, you can end a stream early to prevent unnecessary processing and API requests.

params.name: query
params.description: • Configuration object. See bigquery#query for a complete list of options.

examples.code: var dataset = bigquery.dataset('higher_education');

methods.name: getDatasets
methods.description: List all or some of the datasets in your project.

examples.caption: To control how many API requests are made and page through the results manually, set autoPaginate to false.
If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.
examples.code: bigquery.getDatasets().then(function(datasets) {});

params.name: query.maxApiCalls
params.description: • Maximum number of API calls to make.

params.name: query.pageToken
params.description: • Token returned from a previous call, to request the next page of results.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

params.name: callback.datasets
params.description: • The list of datasets in your project.

methods.name: getDatasetsStream
methods.description: List all or some of the bigquery/dataset objects in your project as a readable object stream.

examples.caption: If you anticipate many results, you can end a stream early to prevent unnecessary processing and API requests.

params.name: query
params.description: • Configuration object. See bigquery#getDatasets for a complete list of options.

methods.name: getJobs
methods.description: Get all of the jobs from your project.

examples.caption: To control how many API requests are made and page through the results manually, set autoPaginate to false.
If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: options.allUsers
params.description: • Display jobs owned by all users in the project.

params.name: options.maxApiCalls
params.description: • Maximum number of API calls to make.

params.name: options.pageToken
params.description: • Token returned from a previous call, to request the next page of results.

params.name: options.projection
params.description: • Restrict information returned to a set of selected fields. Acceptable values are "full", for all job data, and "minimal", to not include the job configuration.

params.name: options.stateFilter
params.description: • Filter for job state. Acceptable values are "done", "pending", and "running". Sending an array to this option performs a disjunction.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

params.name: callback.jobs
params.description: • The list of jobs in your project.

methods.name: getJobsStream
methods.description: List all or some of the bigquery/job objects in your project as a readable object stream.

examples.caption: If you anticipate many results, you can end a stream early to prevent unnecessary processing and API requests.

params.name: query
params.description: • Configuration object. See bigquery#getJobs for a complete list of options.

methods.name: job
methods.description: Create a reference to an existing job.

examples.code: var myExistingJob = bigquery.job('job-id');

methods.name: query
methods.description: Run a query scoped to your project.

examples.caption: Positional SQL parameters are supported.
Or if you prefer to name them, that's also supported.
If you need to use a DATE, DATETIME, TIME, or TIMESTAMP type in your query, see bigquery#date, bigquery#datetime, bigquery#time, and bigquery#timestamp.
To control how many API requests are made and page through the results manually, set autoPaginate to false.
If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: options
params.description: • A string SQL query or configuration object. For all available options, see Jobs: query request body.

params.name: options.maxApiCalls
params.description: • Maximum number of API calls to make.

params.name: options.params
params.description: • For positional SQL parameters, provide an array of values. For named SQL parameters, provide an object which maps each named parameter to its value. The supported types are integers, floats, bigquery#date objects, bigquery#datetime objects, bigquery#time objects, bigquery#timestamp objects, Strings, Booleans, and Objects.

params.name: options.query
params.description: • A query string, following the BigQuery query syntax, of the query to execute.

params.name: options.timeoutMs
params.description: • How long to wait for the query to complete, in milliseconds, before returning. Default is to return immediately. If the timeout passes before the job completes, the request will fail with a TIMEOUT error.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

params.name: callback.rows
params.description: • The list of results from your query.

methods.name: startQuery
methods.description: Run a query as a job. No results are immediately returned. Instead, your callback will be executed with a bigquery/job object that you must ping for the results. See the Job documentation for explanations of how to check on the status of the job.

examples.code: var query = 'SELECT url FROM [publicdata:samples.github_nested] LIMIT 100';

examples.caption: You may pass only a query string, having a new table created to store the results of the query.
examples.code: bigquery.startQuery(query, function(err, job) {});

examples.caption: You can also control the destination table by providing a bigquery/table object.
After you have run startQuery, your query will execute in a job. Your callback is executed with a bigquery/job object so that you may check for the results.
If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: options
params.description: • The configuration object. This must be in the format of the configuration.query property of a Jobs resource. If a string is provided, this is used as the query string, and all other options are defaulted.

params.name: options.destination
params.description: • The table to save the query's results to. If omitted, a new table will be created.

params.name: options.query
params.description: • A query string, following the BigQuery query syntax, of the query to execute.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

params.name: callback.job
params.description: • The newly created job for your query.

exceptions.description: If a Table is not provided as a destination.
